segment.source: Overview about how Group Policy works with Windows Powershell and Internet Explorer 11
segment.target: Overview about how Group Policy works with Windows Powershell and Internet Explorer 11

segment.source: Group Policy, Windows Powershell, and Internet Explorer 11 (Internet Explorer 11 for IT Pros)
segment.target: Group Policy, Windows Powershell, and Internet Explorer 11 (Internet Explorer 11 for IT Pros)

segment.source: Group Policy, Windows Powershell, and Internet Explorer 11
segment.target: Group Policy, Windows Powershell, and Internet Explorer 11

segment.source: Your domain-joined Group Policy Objects (GPOs) can use any of Group Policy-related “cmdlets” that run within Windows PowerShell.
segment.target: Your domain-joined Group Policy Objects (GPOs) can use any of Group Policy-related “cmdlets” that run within Windows PowerShell.

segment.source: Each cmdlet is a single-function command-line tool that can:
segment.target: Each cmdlet is a single-function command-line tool that can:

segment.source: Create, edit, remove, back up, and import GPOs.
segment.target: Create, edit, remove, back up, and import GPOs.

segment.source: Create, update, and remove Group Policy links.
segment.target: Create, update, and remove Group Policy links.

segment.source: Set inheritance flags and permissions on organizational units (OU) and domains.
segment.target: Set inheritance flags and permissions on organizational units (OU) and domains.

segment.source: Configure registry-based policy settings and registry settings for Group Policy preferences.
segment.target: Configure registry-based policy settings and registry settings for Group Policy preferences.

segment.source: For more info about PowerShell and Group Policy management, see Use Windows PowerShell to Manage Group Policy.
segment.target: For more info about PowerShell and Group Policy management, see Use Windows PowerShell to Manage Group Policy.
